speaker: Baley
text: What do you want?

speaker: R. Sammy
text: The boss wants you, Lije. Right away. Soon as you come in.

speaker: Baley
text: All right.

speaker: Baley
text: I said, all right. Go away!

speaker: Simpson
text: Boss wants you, Lije.

speaker: Baley
text: I know. R. Sammy told me.

speaker: Simpson
text: I’d kick R. Sammy’s behind if I weren’t afraid I’d break a leg.

speaker: Simpson
text: I saw Vince Barrett the other day.

speaker: Baley
text: Oh?

speaker: Simpson
text: He was looking for his job back. Or any job in the Department. The poor kid’s desperate, but what could I tell him. R. Sammy’s doing his job and that’s all. The kid has to work a delivery tread on the yeast farms now. He was a bright boy, too. Everyone liked him.

speaker: Baley
text: It’s a thing we’re all living through.

speaker: Baley
text: You want to see me, Commissioner?

speaker: Enderby
text: Sit down, Lije. Sit down.

speaker: Enderby
text: How’s Jessie? And the boy?

speaker: Baley
text: Fine, just fine. And your family?

speaker: Enderby
text: Fine, just fine.

speaker: Baley
text: Commissioner, I wish you wouldn’t send R. Sammy out after me.

speaker: Enderby
text: Well, you know how I feel about those things, Lije. But he’s been put here and I’ve got to use him for something.

speaker: Baley
text: It’s uncomfortable, Commissioner. He tells me you want me and then he stands there. You know what I mean. I have to tell him to go or he just keeps on standing there.

speaker: Enderby
text: Oh, that’s my fault, Lije. I gave him the message to deliver and forgot to tell him specifically to get back to his job when he was through.

speaker: Baley
text: Anyway, you wanted to see me.

speaker: Enderby
text: Yes, Lije, but not for anything easy.

speaker: Enderby
text: I had this arranged specially last year, Lije. I don’t think I’ve showed it to you before. Come over here and take a look. In the old days, all rooms had things like this. They were called “windows.” Did you know that?

speaker: Baley
text: I’ve heard of them.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Come here.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Pardon me, Commissioner, but you’re wearing new glasses, aren’t you?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Yes.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: I broke my old ones three days ago. What with one thing or another I wasn’t able to replace them till this morning. Lije, those three days were hell.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: On account of the glasses?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: And other things, too. I’m getting to that.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: This is the third time this month I’ve watched it rain. Quite a sight, don’t you think?

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: It always seems a waste for all that water to come down on the city. It should restrict itself to the reservoirs.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Lije, you’re a modernist. That’s your trouble. In Medieval times, people lived in the open. I don’t mean on the farms only. I mean in the cities, too. Even in New York. When it rained, they didn’t think of it as waste. They gloried in it. They lived close to nature. It’s healthier, better. The troubles of modern life come from being divorced from nature. Read up on the Coal Century, sometimes.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Look, Julius. Look, Julius, you’re talking about everything except what I came in here for, and it’s worrying me. What is it?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: I’ll get to it, Lije. Let me do it my way. It’s – it’s trouble.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Sure. What isn’t on this planet? More trouble with the R’s?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: In a way, yes, Lije. I stand here and wonder how much more trouble the old world can take. When I put in this window, I wasn’t just letting in the sky once in a while. I let in the City. I look at it and I wonder what will become of it in another century.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: In a way, I’m sorry it’s raining. We can’t see Spacetown.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: I know what Spacetown is like.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: I like the picture from here. It can just be made out in the gap between the two Brunswick Sectors. Low domes spread out. It’s the difference between us and the Spacers. We reach high and crowd close. With them, each family has a dome for itself. One family: one house. And land between each dome. Have you ever spoken to any of the Spacers, Lije?

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: A few times. About a month ago, I spoke to one right here on your intercom.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Yes, I remember. But then I’m getting philosophical. We and they. Different ways of life.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: All right. But what’s so surprising about it? You can’t spread eight million people over Earth in little domes. They’ve got space on their worlds, so let them live their way.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Not everyone is that tolerant about differences in culture. Either among us or among the Spacers.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: All right So what?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: So three days ago, a Spacer died.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Too bad. Something contagious, I hope. A virus. A cold, perhaps.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: What are you talking about?

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: I’m just talking. What did he die of?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: He died of a missing chest. Someone had used a blaster on him.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: What are you talking about?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: I’m talking about murder. You’re a plain-clothes man. You know what murder is.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: But a Spacer! Three days ago?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Yes.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: But who did it? How?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: The Spacers say it was an Earthman.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: It can’t be.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Why not? You don’t like the Spacers. I don’t. Who on Earth does? Someone didn’t like them a little too much, that’s all.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Sure, but—

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: There was the fire at the Los Angeles factories. There was the Berlin R-smashing. There were the riots in Shanghai.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: All right.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: It all points to rising discontent. Maybe to some sort of organization.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Commissioner, I don’t get this. Are you testing me for some reason?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: What?

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Three days ago a Spacer was murdered and the Spacers think the murderer is an Earthman. Till now, nothing’s come out. Is that right? Commissioner, that’s unbelievable. Jehoshaphat, Commissioner, a thing like this would blow New York off the face of the planet if it really happened.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: It’s not as simple as that. Look, Lije, I’ve been out three days. I’ve been in conference with the Mayor. I’ve been out to Spacetown. I’ve been down in Washington, talking to the Terrestrial Bureau of Investigation.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Oh? And what do the Terries have to say?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: They say it’s our baby. It’s inside city limits. Spacetown is under New York jurisdiction.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: But with extraterritorial rights.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: I know. I’m coming to that.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: The Spacers can run the show.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Wait a minute, Lije, don’t rush me. I’m trying to talk this over, friend to friend. I want you to know my position. I was there when the news broke. I had an appointment with him – with Roj Nemennuh Sarton.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: The victim?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: The victim.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Five minutes more and I, myself, would have discovered the body. What a shock that would have been. As it was, it was brutal, brutal. They met me and told me. It started a three-day nightmare, Lije. That on top of having everything blur on me and having no time to replace my glasses for days. That won’t happen again, at least. I’ve ordered three pairs.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: It’s a devil of a position. As you say, the Spacers have extraterritorial rights. They can insist on their own investigation, make whatever report they wish to their home governments. The Outer Worlds could use this as an excuse to pile on indemnity charges. You know how that would sit with the population.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: It would be political suicide for the White House to agree to pay.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: And another kind of suicide not to pay.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: You don’t have to draw me a picture.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Then you see. Pay or not pay, it’s trouble. The only way out is to find the murderer on our own and hand him over to the Spacers. It’s up to us.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Why not give it to the TBI? Even if it is our jurisdiction from a legalistic viewpoint, there’s the question of interstellar relations—

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: The TBI won’t touch it. This is hot and it’s in our lap.
The TBI won’t touch it This is hot and it’s in our lap.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: And it’s not good, Lije. Every one of us stands the chance of being out of a job.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Replace us all? Nuts. The trained men to do it with don’t exist.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: R’s, they exist.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: What?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: R. Sammy is just a beginning. He runs errands. Others can patrol the expressways. Damn it man, I know the Spacers better than you do, and I know what they’re doing. There are R’s that can do your work and mine. We can be declassified. Don’t think differently. And at our age, to hit the labor pool …

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: All right.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Sorry, Lije.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: When did all this replacement business come up?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Look, you’re being naïve, Lije. It’s been happening all along. It’s been happening for twenty-five years, ever since the Spacers came. You know that. It’s just beginning to reach higher, that’s all. If we muff this case, it’s a big, long step toward the point where we can stop looking forward to collecting our pension-tab booklets. On the other hand, Lije, if we handle the matter well, it can shove that point far into the future. And it would be a particular break for you.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: For me?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: You’ll be the operative in charge, Lije.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: I don’t rate it, Commissioner. I’m a C-5, that’s all.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: You want a C-6 rating, don’t you?

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: I want it. Sure. Why wouldn’t I? But what would I get if I couldn’t break the case?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Why wouldn’t you break it, Lije? You’re a good man. You’re one of the best we have.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: But there are half a dozen men with higher ratings in my department section. Why should they be passed over?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Two reasons. You’re not just another detective to me, Lije. We’re friends, too. I’m not forgetting we were in college together. Sometimes it may look as though I have forgotten, but that’s the fault of rating. I’m Commissioner, and you know what that means. But I’m still your friend and this is a tremendous chance for the right person. I want you to have it.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: That’s one reason.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: The second reason is that I think you’re my friend. I need a favor.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: What sort of favor?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: I want you to take on a Spacer partner in this deal. That was the condition the Spacers made. They’ve agreed not to report the murder; they’ve agreed to leave the investigation in our hands. In return, they insist one of their own agents be in on the deal, the whole deal.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: It sounds like they don’t trust us altogether.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Surely you see their point. If this is mishandled, a number of them will be in trouble with their own governments. I’ll give them the benefit of the doubt, Lije. I’m willing to believe they mean well.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: I’m sure they do, Commissioner. That’s the trouble with them.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Are you willing to take on a Spacer partner, Lije?

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: You’re asking that as a favor?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: I want you to take on a Spacer partner in this deal. That was the condition the Spacers made. They’ve agreed not to report the murder; they’ve agreed to leave the investigation in our hands. In return, they insist one of their own agents be in on the deal, the whole deal.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: It sounds like they don’t trust us altogether.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Surely you see their point. If this is mishandled, a number of them will be in trouble with their own governments. I’ll give them the benefit of the doubt, Lije. I’m willing to believe they mean well.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: I’m sure they do, Commissioner. That’s the trouble with them.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Are you willing to take on a Spacer partner, Lije?

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: You’re asking that as a favor?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Yes, I’m asking you to take the job with all the conditions the Spacers have set up.
Yes, I’m asking you to take the job with all the conditions the Spacers have set up.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: I’ll take a Spacer partner, Commissioner.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Thanks, Lije. He’ll have to live with you.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Oh, now, hold on.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: I know. I know. But you’ve got a large apartment, Lije. Three rooms. Only one child. You can put him up. He’ll be no trouble. No trouble at all. And it’s necessary.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Jessie won’t like it. I know that.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: You tell Jessie, that if you do this for me, I’ll do what I can when this is all over to jump you a grade. C-7, Lije. C-7!

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: All right, Commissioner, it’s a deal.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: There’s something else?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: One more item.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Which is?
There’s something else?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: One more item.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Which is?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: The name of your partner.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: What difference does that make?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: The Spacers have peculiar ways. The partner they’re supplying isn’t – isn’t …

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Just a minute!

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: You’ve got to, Lije. You’ve got to. There’s no way out.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: Stay at my apartment? A thing like that?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: As a friend, please!

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: No. No!

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: Lije, I can’t trust anyone else in this. Do I have to spell it out for you? We’ve got to work with the Spacers. We’ve got to succeed, if we’re to keep the indemnity ships away from Earth. But we can’t succeed just any old way. You’ll be partnered with one of their R’s. If he breaks the case, if he can report that we’re incompetent, we’re ruined, anyway. We, as a department. You see that, don’t you? So you’ve got a delicate job on your hands. You’ve got to work with him, but see to it that you solve the case and not he. Understand?

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: You mean co-operate with him 100 per cent, except that I cut his throat? Pat him on the back with a knife in my hand?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: What else can we do? There’s no other way out.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: I don’t know what Jessie will say.

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: I’ll talk to her, if you want me to.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: No, Commissioner.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: What’s my partner’s name?

emotion.speaker: Enderby
emotion.text: R. Daneel Olivaw.

emotion.speaker: Baley
emotion.text: This isn’t a time for euphemism, Commissioner. I’m taking the job, so let’s use his full name. Robot Daneel Olivaw.
